text:
“…just like my conviction that I needed to be seen as white to be worthy, seen as a woman to escape those men who would have beaten me up had they realized they desired a man.”⁣
⁣
Fairest is a complex coming-of-age memoir that is equal parts tough and beautiful. Meredith Talusan recounts transition in two forms: geographical and gender. Starting off with her childhood in the Philippines, where she always stood out as an Albino “sun child” boy and as she immigrates to the US, where she spends her adolescence as a gay man and how she eventually transitioned as a trans woman. From childhood, there were flecks of neglect from parents and a longing for belonging which would surface as she grows through the years. ⁣
⁣
With typical, old-school Filipino colonial mentality ingrained in her since childhood, the idea of America held great promise for Talusan. As she settles in the US, she often passed as an American and experienced “white privilege” firsthand. This brings upon the realization that whiteness is just an illusion and how prevalent colorism is up to this day. While dealing with confusion with identity, she also had to confront her stand with gender. Eagerly enlisting for a Gender Studies class in Harvard, Talusan educates herself in gender, sexuality and queer theory. She makes us privy to her clandestine awakening as she explores through her sexuality with hookups, trips to baths and her romantic relationships. Erratically and viscerally, she narrates her evolution from being a gay man with a fervent desire for womanhood until eventually deciding to become a trans woman. ⁣
⁣
This memoir is honest, sometimes frustrating and in the end, liberating—fearlessly reflecting on the complexities of gender, race and identity. I know that I will never be able to fully understand Talusan’s plight in its entirety but it was an awakening to hear her story. ⁣
⁣

🌈 #PridenBlazers Book Rec 🌈 

“I came to understand that what I wanted was to be seen as my complete self — my gender, my race, my history — without being judged because of it. I wanted people close to me to see an albino person who had learned how to look and act white so the world would more readily accept her, and understand how that had been a key part of her survival.” 

I know I’m super late to this one, but! Definitely another addition to the best queer memoirs to add to your library! I started this one digitally last year and put it down, but I am so so glad I picked it back up this year because it is truly incredible. From her time as a child in the Philippines, to her tenure at Harvard passing as a white, blond gay man, to her post-Harvard years and her transition, Meredith tells her story with grace, care, intelligence, and nuance, and I was hooked. Her meditations on intersectional self and the many different ways she could have been happy in other kinds of lives if she had made different choices really resonated with me, as someone who also is constantly thinking about the road not traveled and the path not taken. Pick this one up ASAP, friends! And just look at that perfectly beautiful rainbow paperback cover for Pride! 😍🌈

Fairest by Marissa Meyer:
⭐️⭐️⭐️⭐️/5

I have been putting off reading this book for SO long. I got it right after I finished reading The Lunar Chronicles because I was sad the series had ended, and I needed more time with the characters. Then, for some reason, I never got around to reading it. After a bit of time had gone by, I wasn’t as obsessed with the series anymore so Fairest went way down on my TBR.

That being said, I’m SO happy I finally picked up this book! (Thanks @bookwaffles for pushing me 😂) It took me a little bit to get into it, but I think that happens to me with all books these days. It was fascinating to learn about Levana’s villain origin story. It made me view her as much more complex than I did initially. This story deals with themes of self-esteem, unrequited love, and familial abuse. For being such a short book, I cannot stop thinking about it!

I love how Meyer pulls you into the fairytale, and effortlessly incorporates powerful quotes into the narrative. If you enjoyed The Lunar Chronicles, I highly recommend this book. I feel like even non-readers of the initial series could love this story.

The only thing that kept Fairest from being 5 stars is that is didn’t absolutely WOW me. Don’t get me wrong, I absolutely enjoyed it, and it’s still on my mind a week later. But it wasn’t AMAZING if you know what I mean. Swipe to see some of my favorite quotes from the book. 💗

Fairest by Marissa Meyer is a companion novel to The Lunar Chronicles series, and I’m reading it as a part of my reread! This book tells the story of Queen Levana, the evil ruler of Luna. As she grows from a teenager to an adult, her ambition takes her down a very dark path, making her into the villain she was in the original series. This book was really well written, although it has a very different feel from the rest of the series. This book was less action packed and more of a deep dive into Levana’s character, which made it much more disturbing than the others. The author did an amazing job portraying Levana; at times, this book almost made me feel bad for her. Also, the way she justified her terrible actions and thought she was going the right thing was really cool; it made her a well rounded villain. A lot of YA villains don’t have much depth, but Levana was definitely an exception. It was also interesting to see Channary’s character, since she was only mentioned in the main series. If you enjoyed The Lunar Chronicles this is a must read! I would give it a 9.4/10!

🌌Título: Fairest.
🌌Autora: Marissa Meyer. 🌌Forma parte de la saga: Crónicas Lunares (precuela).
*
• El amor puede ser una maravillosa bendición o un increíble veneno. En este relato de amor y guerra, codicia y muerte... Levana es la mujer que por amor lo destruyó todo a su paso y fue capaz de cometer sus secretos más oscuros 🌌👑♟⚔️🖤.
*
📝Opinión: Este delgado libro está lleno de sorpresas, tragedias, dolor y codicia... La trama es muy interesante porque se trata de la propia historia de la villana de estas crónicas, Levana me parece un personaje roto y destructor, es capaz de cometer terribles atrocidades y de no dejar nada a su paso si así lo desea. Lo que hizo, lo que le hizo a los personajes... ah, es terrible y yo me quedé asqueada y con impotencia en el corazón con lo que le hizo a un hombre, que si ya leíste la historia sabrás de quién estoy hablando 😭, nooo. A pesar de todo eso, me encantó la narración de la autora y su manera de engancharte a la historia, es genial. No podía parar de leer porque quería saber cómo terminaba. 
Recomendación: El libro se lee después de haber leído “Cress” ya que de esa forma podrás comprender el siguiente libro de “Winter”. Yo le doy: 4/5 ⭐️
Emoción al leer: 😰
